did.unittitle: Guide to the Herman F. Mark Collection, 1918-2013

repository.corpname: Poly Archives at Bern Dibner Library of Science and Technology

did.abstract: The Herman Mark Collection documents the personal and profession life of Herman Francis Mark, the Father of Polymer Science. During his fifty years at the Polytechnic Institute of Brooklyn, Mark developed the field of polymer science in the United States, published over 600 articles, and founded the Institute of Polymer Research, the first graduate program of its kind in America.
did.physloc: Poly Archives & Special Collections Bern Dibner Library of Science and Technology 5 MetroTech Center Brooklyn, NY 11201 Phone: (718) 260-3943 Fax: (718) 260-3756 archives@library.poly.edu

arrangement.head: Arrangement note
arrangement.p: This collection is arranged into eleven series, by subject:

list.head: List
list.item: Polytechnic Institute of Brooklyn and the Polymer Research Institute

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation note
prefercite.p: Published citations should take the following form:
Identification of item, date; RG-002: Herman Mark Collection; box number; folder number; Poly Archives & Special Collections at Bern Dibner Library of Science and Technology.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The collection contains professional and personal items of Herman Mark, including publications, pre-prints and drafts, notes, photographs, slides, awards, correspondence, festschrift, government documents, professional contacts, audio and video tapes. The VHS and U-matic tapes were digitized in 2013 and are stored on a local server.

The bulk of the collection relates to Mark's tenure at the Polytechnic Institute of Brooklyn (1940-1990), although some documents and photographs detail his early years in Vienna and his final years in Texas. Mark was a beloved figure at Polytechnic and beyond, as documented by his Polytechnic birthday symposia celebrations and birthday wishes from around the world.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use note
userestrict.p: Permission to publish materials must be obtained from:
Poly Archives & Special Collections Bern Dibner Library of Science and Technology 5 MetroTech Center Brooklyn, NY 11201

bioghist.head: Biographical/Historical note
bioghist.p: Herman Francis Mark, The Father of Polymer Science, was born in Vienna on May 3, 1895. Although his schooling was interrupted by World War I, in which he served on the front lines as well as spending a year as a prisoner of war, he managed to complete his doctoral dissertation on the synthesis and characterization of the pentaphenyl ethyl free radical. His doctoral advisor, Wilhelm Schlenk, subsequently offered Mark a position at the University of Berlin in 1921.

Mark's position at the university had barely begun when he was offered a job at the Institute for Fiber Research at the Kaiser Wilhelm Institute. Here he worked on projects including x-ray crystallographic, refraction, and polarization studies. In 1926 he took a position at I.G. Farbenindustrie to study the production of synthetic fibers. At the start of World War II, he sought employment outside of Germany, becoming a professor of chemistry at the University of Vienna in 1932. There he designed a curriculum in polymer chemistry.

With the Nazi threat looming, Mark and his family prepared to escape Europe by covertly buying bits of platinum wire and twisting it into coat hangers in order to accumulate money for travel and a new life. By the time the Mark family escaped to Canada, they had amassed $50,000 in platinum wire.

Herman Mark joined the Polytechnic Institute of Brooklyn (PIB) as an adjunct professor in 1940. Mark's position at PIB, as well as his relationships with DuPont and the wartime Office of Scientific Research and Development, led to further developments in polymer research. In 1947, the Institute of Polymer Research was founded at PIB; the first graduate program of its kind in America. Mark continued his relationship with PIB for over 50 years. He died in 1992.

The discipline of polymer science that Mark helped to establish is now a vital branch of chemistry. Polymers, macromolecules formed synthetically by uniting monomers, have high viscosity, elasticity, and strength. The first synthetic fiber, nylon, was a result of Mark's work in polymers. Today many scientific companies conduct polymer research.
"Herman Francis Mark" nap.edu. The National Academies Press Biographical Memoirs. n.d. Web. 29 Aug. 2012.
Rodengen, Jeffrey L, and Mickey Murphy. Changing the World: Polytechnic University - - the First 150 Years. Fort Lauderdale, FL: Write Stuff Enterprises, Inc, 2005. Print.

arrangement.head: Arrangement note
arrangement.p: These files were in a vertical file cabinet, which was moved from Professor Mark's office to Dibner Library some time in the 1990s. The cabinet contained two sets of alphabetized files, and although there is much overlap between the file names and date ranges between these two sets, Professor Mark's original order is maintained as two sets with the original dividers.

did.unittitle: Series VI: Polytechnic Institute of Brooklyn and the Polymer Research Institute
Subseries A: Mark Birthday Symposia and Festschrift

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Professor Mark received birthday letters, cards, and festschrift from Europe, Asia, North America, South America, and the Middle East. Notable well-wishers include President Ronald Reagan, Mayor Ed Koch, and Polytechnic's Bern Dibner.
